doc.previous: Hilbert's basis theorem has some immediate corollaries:
doc.after: An ideal Q of a ring is said to be primary if Q is proper and whenever xy â Q, either x â Q or yn â Q for some positive integer n. In Z, the primary ideals are precisely the ideals of the form (pe) where p is prime and e is a positive integer. Thus, a primary decomposition of (n) corresponds to representing (n) as the intersection of finitely many primary ideals.
